answer_html: In other words, there exists a bijective function \(f: C \rightarrow \mathbb{N}.\) (Equivalently, there exists a bijective function \(g: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow C.\))
answer_latex:
In other words, there exists a
bijective function $f: C \rightarrow \mathbb{N}.$ (Equivalently, there
exists a bijective function $g: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow C.$)
hints_html: An example is not a definition. But it sure helps to have some examples and counter-examples to understand what you are trying to define.
hints_latex:
An example is \textbf{not} a definition. But it sure helps to have some
examples and counter-examples to understand what you are trying to
define.
hints_raw: An example is '''not''' a definition. But it sure helps to have some examples and counter-examples to understand what you are trying to define.
question: 3 (b)
sols_html: A set C is countable if it has the same cardinality as the set \(\mathbb{N}\) of natural numbers. In other words, there exists a bijective function \(f: C \rightarrow \mathbb{N}.\) (Equivalently, there exists a bijective function \(g: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow C.\))
sols_latex:
A set \emph{C} is countable if it has the same cardinality as the set
$\mathbb{N}$ of natural numbers. In other words, there exists a
bijective function $f: C \rightarrow \mathbb{N}.$ (Equivalently, there
exists a bijective function $g: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow C.$)
sols_raw: A set ''C'' is countable if it has the same cardinality as the set <math>\mathbb{N}</math> of natural numbers. In other words, there exists a bijective function <math>f: C \rightarrow \mathbb{N}.</math> (Equivalently, there exists a bijective function <math>g: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow C.</math>)
statement_html: Define what it means for a set C to be countable.
statement_latex: Define what it means for a set \emph{C} to be countable.
statement_raw: Define what it means for a set ''C'' to be countable.
